thread.title: Rick Nash scores goal, 700th career point without actually shooting the puck
thread.title_full: Rick Nash scores goal, 700th career point without actually shooting the puck

title: Rick Nash scores goal, 700th career point without actually shooting the puck
text:
Rick Nash scores goal, 700th career point without actually shooting the puck Resize Text By Michael Smith October 22 at 10:34 PM Rick Nash didn’t even need to shoot to score Thursday. (Jay LaPrete/Associated Press) 
Wayne Gretzky famously said that you miss 100 percent of the shots you don’t take. That rule does not apply to the New York Rangers’ Rick Nash. 
[ Gretzky debuts new clothing line in Toronto ] 
Nash was hooked on a breakaway while the Arizona Coyotes had an empty net, and as a result, was awarded his first goal of the season even though the puck never crossed the goal line. The goal, Nash’s first of the year, was also his 700th career point. Rick Nash's 700th career point is a goal in which the puck never enters the net pic.twitter.com/MJtHBJdHox 
— Stephanie (@myregularface) October 23, 2015 
The reasoning for the goal that wasn’t a goal can be found right in the NHL rule book in almost oddly specific detail: let's try this again: a few fans not sure of this rule regarding the nash goal – here it is in the rulebook 25.1 pic.twitter.com/oLg1tqdhkp
